(!) Gulko recognised the potency that White could attack with using his bishops and queen. One variation is 16...0-0 17.Nb3 Rfc8 18.Qg4... Instead Black (in the face of a bishop swap off) can look forward to attacking the c-pawn after castling and mobilising his rooks.

(!) Topalov said he considered a sacrifice with 17.a4... After which 17...Bxa4 18.Ba3... Stops Black from castling else he face complications. He also said that he wouldn't mind 17...Bxd3 18.cxd3... Since Black is then unable to target c2. However, Topalov said he didn't sacrifice because after 17...Bxa4 18.Ba3 comes 18...Qc3! And threats of 19...Qxd3! And 19...Qxa3 arise.
The options for White's pieces, the threat on b5 and the fact that Black's rooks appear to be threatened from being able to mobilise compensate for the 'lost' material. However.....
The options for White's pieces, the threat on b5 and the fact that Black's rooks appear to be threatened from being able to mobilise compensate for the 'lost' material. However.....
(!) Gulko said 19.Bxb5 Qxc2 20.Bxa4 Qxa4 was acceptable for him.
(!) Topalov refuses to accept the counter-sacrifice. But.....
(!) "No, I MUST insist...!" Black recognises the favourable stance after 20.Bxc4? bxc4
Topalov intends to continue with Bb4 and c3. He can also exchange his weak b3-knight with Nb3-d2-xc4.
White's bishops are the obvious asset of this position. However, Topalov pointed out that after 24.Bd6 Re4 25.Qd2 Rxe1+ and 26...Qxc2, that Black can regain composure with Qe4 or Kd8.
